definition:
\begin{definition}
    \label{definition:PreHilbert}
    A pre Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ over ${\mathsf{{C}}}$ is a
    ${\mathsf{{C}}}$-module with inner product ${\left\langle{{\cdot,\cdot}}\right\rangle}:
    \mathcal{H} \times \mathcal{H} \to {\mathsf{{C}}}$ such that
    \begin{enumerate}
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi, z\psi + w \chi}}\right\rangle} = z {\left\langle{{\phi,\psi}}\right\rangle} + w
        {\left\langle{{\phi,\chi}}\right\rangle}$ for $\phi,\psi,\chi \in \mathcal{H}$ and $z,w
        \in {\mathsf{{C}}}$.
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi,\psi}}\right\rangle} = \overline{{{\left\langle{{\psi,\phi}}\right\rangle}}}$ for $\phi, \psi \in
        \mathcal{H}$.
    \item ${\left\langle{{\phi,\phi}}\right\rangle} > 0$ for $\phi \ne 0$.
    \end{enumerate}
\

\begin{definition}
    \label{definition:starAlg}
    An associative algebra $\mathcal{A}$ over ${\mathsf{{C}}}$ is called
    $^*$-algebra if it is equipped with an involutive anti-linear
    anti-automorphism $^*:\mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{A}$, called the
    $^*$-involution. A $^*$-homomorphism $\Phi: \mathcal{A} \to
    \mathcal{B}$ between $^*$-algebras is an algebra morphism with
    $\Phi(A^*) = \Phi(A)^*$.
\

\begin{definition}
    \label{definition:SuffPos}
    A $^*$-algebra $\mathcal{A}$ over ${\mathsf{{C}}}$ has sufficiently many
    positive linear functionals if for any $0 \ne H = H^* \in
    \mathcal{A}$ there exists a positive functional $\omega$ with
    $\omega(H) \ne 0$.
\

\begin{definition}[Strong Morita equivalence \protect{\cite{bursztyn.waldmann:2001a}}]
    \label{definition:morita}
    Two unital $^*$-al\-ge\-bras $\mathcal{A}$, $\mathcal{B}$ are
    called strongly Morita equivalent if one finds a bimodule
    $\mathcal{E}$ with compatible completely positive inner products
    which are both full.
\
